civil_procedure.name: SUBJECT-MATTER JURISDICTION
civil_procedure.subject: civil_procedure
civil_procedure.rule_statement: Federal courts need subject-matter jurisdiction via federal question, diversity exceeding $75,000 with complete diversity, or supplemental claims sharing common nucleus with anchor.

civil_procedure.name: PERSONAL JURISDICTION
civil_procedure.subject: civil_procedure
civil_procedure.rule_statement: State court exercises personal jurisdiction where statute authorizes and Due Process satisfied through minimum contacts, purposeful availment, foreseeability, and fairness plus notice.

civil_procedure.name: Subject Matter Jurisdiction - Federal Question
civil_procedure.subject: civil_procedure
civil_procedure.rule_statement: Claim arises under federal law

civil_procedure.name: Subject Matter Jurisdiction - Diversity
civil_procedure.subject: civil_procedure
civil_procedure.rule_statement: Complete diversity + $75K

civil_procedure.name: Personal Jurisdiction - Minimum Contacts
civil_procedure.subject: civil_procedure
civil_procedure.rule_statement: Purposeful availment required

civil_procedure.name: Personal Jurisdiction - Fair Play
civil_procedure.subject: civil_procedure
civil_procedure.rule_statement: Burden, forum interest, efficiency

civil_procedure.name: Service of Process

civil_procedure.rule_statement: Proper notice required for jurisdiction

constitutional_law.name: Judicial Power & Justiciability
constitutional_law.subject: constitutional_law
constitutional_law.rule_statement: Case-or-controversy requirement demands standing (injury, causation, redressability), ripeness, and absence of mootness or political questions.

constitutional_law.name: Federal Legislative Power
constitutional_law.subject: constitutional_law
constitutional_law.rule_statement: Congress operates within enumerated powers; Commerce Clause covers channels, instrumentalities, and substantial economic effects; Necessary & Proper clause implements enumerated powers.

constitutional_law.name: Executive Power
constitutional_law.subject: constitutional_law
constitutional_law.rule_statement: Presidential power peaks with congressional authorization, declines in twilight zones, bottomed out when defying Congress.

constitutional_law.name: Federalism & State Power
constitutional_law.subject: constitutional_law
constitutional_law.rule_statement: Tenth Amendment reserves unenumerated powers; Supremacy Clause preempts conflicts; dormant Commerce Clause prevents discriminatory burdens; states cannot tax the federal government.
common_traps: Article IV Privileges & Immunities limited to citizens

constitutional_law.name: Individual Rights
constitutional_law.subject: constitutional_law
constitutional_law.rule_statement: Procedural DP requires notice + hearing for life/liberty/property; substantive DP protects fundamental rights via strict scrutiny, otherwise rational basis.
common_traps: undue burden standard for abortion (not strict scrutiny).

constitutional_law.name: Equal Protection
constitutional_law.subject: constitutional_law
constitutional_law.rule_statement: Classification triggers scrutiny: suspect (strict), quasi-suspect (intermediate), others (rational basis); fundamental rights also trigger strict scrutiny.

constitutional_law.name: First Amendment
constitutional_law.subject: constitutional_law
constitutional_law.rule_statement: Content-based regulations = strict scrutiny; content-neutral TPM = intermediate; unprotected categories include incitement, obscenity, fighting words, true threats, child pornography.

constitutional_law.name: FEDERAL POWERS & SUPREMACY
constitutional_law.subject: constitutional_law
constitutional_law.rule_statement: Congress legislates through enumerated powers, Necessary and Proper Clause, Commerce channels or substantial effects, while Supremacy Clause preempts conflicting state actions within enumerated sphere.

constitutional_law.name: INDIVIDUAL RIGHTS & SCRUTINY
constitutional_law.subject: constitutional_law
constitutional_law.rule_statement: Government action triggering individual rights receives strict, intermediate, or rational basis scrutiny depending on classification or burden, requiring tailored means and adequate governmental objectives.

constitutional_law.name: Commerce Clause - Channels
constitutional_law.subject: constitutional_law
constitutional_law.rule_statement: Congress can regulate channels of commerce

constitutional_law.name: Commerce Clause - Instrumentalities
constitutional_law.subject: constitutional_law
constitutional_law.rule_statement: Regulation of instrumentalities

constitutional_law.name: Commerce Clause - Substantial Effects
constitutional_law.subject: constitutional_law
constitutional_law.rule_statement: Economic activity affecting commerce

constitutional_law.name: Necessary and Proper
constitutional_law.subject: constitutional_law
constitutional_law.rule_statement: Means rationally related to enumerated power

constitutional_law.name: Dormant Commerce Clause

contracts.name: Terms & Interpretation
contracts.subject: contracts
contracts.rule_statement: Common law mirror-image; UCC gap fillers; parol evidence.

contracts.name: Performance & Breach
contracts.subject: contracts
contracts.rule_statement: Common law substantial performance vs material breach; UCC perfect tender.

contracts.name: UCC Delivery, Title & Risk of Loss
contracts.subject: contracts
common_traps: Breach always keeps risk on breaching party; “FOB plant” is shipment

contracts.name: Acceptance, Rejection & Revocation (UCC)
contracts.subject: contracts
common_traps: Using goods extensively after discovering defect can bar revocation; COD shipments limit inspection rights.

contracts.name: Excuse: Impossibility, Impracticability, Frustration
contracts.subject: contracts
common_traps: Mere increased cost insufficient unless extreme; assuming price fluctuation risk defeats excuse.

contracts.name: Modification, Accord & Satisfaction, Novation
contracts.subject: contracts
common_traps: Modification of firm offer beyond three months requires fresh consideration; distinguishing novation from assignment/delegation.

contracts.name: Warranties (UCC & Common)
contracts.subject: contracts
common_traps: Statements of opinion/puffery not express warranties; “as is” doesn’t negate express warranties; limitations failing essential purpose open door to full UCC remedies.

contracts.name: OFFER, ACCEPTANCE, CONSIDERATION
contracts.subject: contracts
contracts.rule_statement: Valid contract needs offer showing commitment, acceptance mirroring material terms, and consideration or substitute reliance creating bargained-for exchange with mutual assent and capacity.

contracts.name: PERFORMANCE, BREACH, REMEDIES
contracts.subject: contracts
contracts.rule_statement: Performance judged by strict compliance for non-UCC or perfect tender under Article 2; material breach excuses; remedies include expectation, reliance, restitution, specific performance.

contracts.name: FORMATION – FOCI CHECKLIST
contracts.subject: contracts
common_traps: Option contracts (need consideration unless UCC firm offer ≤ 3 months, signed by merchant).
Mailbox rule exceptions: option, improperly addressed, rejection before acceptance.

contracts.name: Contract Remedy 2
contracts.subject: contracts
contracts.rule_statement: Remedies put nonbreaching party in position if performed

criminal_law.name: Elements of Crimes
criminal_law.subject: criminal_law
criminal_law.rule_statement: Every offense needs a voluntary act (or qualifying omission), the requisite mental state, concurrence, and causation.
common_traps: transferred intent limited to same crime

criminal_law.name: Homicide Offenses
criminal_law.subject: criminal_law
criminal_law.rule_statement: Murder = unlawful killing with malice aforethought (intent to kill, intent to seriously injure, depraved heart, felony murder). Manslaughter lacks malice.
common_traps: Instant premeditation allowed; deadly weapon inference; felony-murder merger; cooling-off defeats voluntary manslaughter; police/victim killings not felony murder (agency theory).

criminal_law.name: Other Crimes Against Persons
criminal_law.subject: criminal_law
common_traps: Battery requires only intent to touch; assault has two theories; kidnapping needs substantial movement; mistake of age no defense to statutory rape.

criminal_law.name: Property Crimes
criminal_law.subject: criminal_law
common_traps: Intent at time of taking (larceny); assaultive felonies merge; force must accompany taking for robbery; burglary intent must pre-exist entry.

criminal_law.name: Inchoate Crimes
criminal_law.subject: criminal_law
common_traps: Solicitation complete without acceptance; conspiracy survives completed offense; attempt always specific intent; abandonment defense limited (MPC).

criminal_law.name: Accomplice & Accessory Liability
criminal_law.subject: criminal_law
common_traps: Mere presence insufficient; dual intent requirement; accomplice liability remains even if principal acquitted; accessory after fact not liable for underlying offense.

criminal_law.name: Defenses
criminal_law.subject: criminal_law
common_traps: Duress unavailable for murder; voluntary intoxication limited; entrapment fails if predisposed; mistaking age no defense to statutory rape.

criminal_law.name: MENS REA & HOMICIDE
criminal_law.subject: criminal_law
criminal_law.rule_statement: Criminal liability requires actus reus with mens rea of purpose, knowledge, recklessness, or negligence; homicide classifications depend on malice aforethought, intent, depraved heart, felony murder.

criminal_law.name: Actus Reus
criminal_law.subject: criminal_law
criminal_law.rule_statement: Voluntary act or omission with legal duty

criminal_law.name: Mens Rea - Purpose
criminal_law.subject: criminal_law
criminal_law.rule_statement: Conscious objective to cause result

criminal_law.name: Mens Rea - Knowledge
criminal_law.subject: criminal_law
criminal_law.rule_statement: Awareness of conduct and circumstances

criminal_law.name: Felony Murder
criminal_law.subject: criminal_law
criminal_law.rule_statement: Killing during inherently dangerous felony

criminal_law.name: Voluntary Manslaughter
criminal_law.subject: criminal_law
criminal_law.rule_statement: Intentional killing with adequate provocation

criminal_law.name: Larceny
criminal_law.subject: criminal_law
criminal_law.rule_statement: Trespassory taking and carrying away with intent to steal

criminal_law.rule_statement: Defenses negate elements or justify/excuse conduct
criminal_law.teach: DEFENSES = Negate element OR justify OR excuse

criminal_procedure.name: Exclusionary Rule
criminal_procedure.subject: criminal_procedure
common_traps: Miranda violations (non-Miranda statements may be used for impeachment)

criminal_procedure.name: SEARCH, SEIZURE, STATEMENTS
criminal_procedure.subject: criminal_procedure
criminal_procedure.rule_statement: Fourth Amendment protects reasonable expectations of privacy; warrants need probable cause and particularity; exclusionary rule suppressed violations; Fifth and Sixth regulate interrogation, counsel, identifications.

criminal_procedure.name: Standing - Fourth Amendment
criminal_procedure.subject: criminal_procedure
criminal_procedure.rule_statement: Reasonable expectation of privacy required

criminal_procedure.name: Probable Cause
criminal_procedure.subject: criminal_procedure
criminal_procedure.rule_statement: Fair probability evidence of crime exists

criminal_procedure.name: Search Incident to Arrest
criminal_procedure.subject: criminal_procedure
criminal_procedure.rule_statement: Contemporaneous search of person and wingspan

criminal_procedure.name: Automobile Exception
criminal_procedure.subject: criminal_procedure
criminal_procedure.rule_statement: Warrantless search with probable cause and mobility

criminal_procedure.name: Plain View Doctrine
criminal_procedure.subject: criminal_procedure
criminal_procedure.rule_statement: Seizure if lawfully present and incriminating evident

criminal_procedure.name: Miranda Custody
criminal_procedure.subject: criminal_procedure
criminal_procedure.rule_statement: Reasonable person would not feel free to leave

criminal_procedure.name: Miranda Invocation
criminal_procedure.subject: criminal_procedure
criminal_procedure.rule_statement: Unambiguous request for counsel or silence

criminal_procedure.name: Sixth Amendment Attachment
criminal_procedure.subject: criminal_procedure
criminal_procedure.rule_statement: Right to counsel attaches at formal charges

criminal_procedure.name: Deliberate Elicitation
criminal_procedure.subject: criminal_procedure
criminal_procedure.rule_statement: Officers cannot elicit statements after charges

evidence.name: Present Sense Impression (803(1))
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Statement describing event made while declarant perceiving event or immediately thereafter
evidence.teach: PRESENT SENSE = Describing what you see RIGHT NOW. No time to lie.
evidence.question: Witness testifies: "As car ran red light, passenger said 'That car just ran the light!'" Hearsay exception?
evidence.why: Statement describing event while/immediately after perceiving = present sense impression (803(1))

evidence.name: Excited Utterance (803(2))
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Statement relating to startling event made while under stress of excitement caused by event
elements: Made while under stress of excitement
common_traps: Requiring immediate statement (can be later if still excited)
evidence.teach: EXCITED UTTERANCE = Startling event + still excited when speaking. Adrenaline = no lying.
evidence.question: 2 hours after accident, victim (still shaking/crying) says "He ran the light!" Exception?
evidence.why: Time doesn't matter if still under stress of excitement. Still shaking = still excited.

evidence.name: State of Mind Exception (803(3))
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Statement of declarant's then-existing mental/emotional/physical condition
exceptions: Cannot prove fact remembered/believed (Hillmon doctrine limits)
policy_rationales: People know their own mental state
common_traps: Using past statements about mental state
evidence.teach: STATE OF MIND = "I feel X right now" OK. "I felt X yesterday" NOT OK.
evidence.question: Will contest. Statement "I intend to leave all to charity" admissible for intent?
evidence.why: Then-existing intent admissible under 803(3). Intent to do future act = state of mind.

evidence.name: Statements for Medical Diagnosis (803(4))
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Statements made for medical diagnosis/treatment describing symptoms, cause, or source
policy_rationales: People don't lie to their doctors
common_traps: Thinking any statement to doctor qualifies
evidence.teach: MEDICAL STATEMENTS = To get treated right, you tell truth. But NOT fault/blame.
evidence.question: Patient tells doctor: "My husband hit me." Admissible for medical diagnosis?
evidence.why: Source of injury pertinent to diagnosis/treatment. "Who" matters for domestic violence treatment.

evidence.name: Business Records Exception (803(6))
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Record of regularly conducted activity, made at/near time by person with knowledge, kept in regular course
exceptions: Prepared for litigation may be excluded
evidence.teach: BUSINESS RECORDS = Regular + routine + reliable. Need foundation witness.
evidence.question: Hospital record of patient vitals. Nurse who recorded it unavailable. Admissible?
evidence.why: Business record if foundation laid (custodian can testify about regular practice). Recorder need not testify.

evidence.name: Public Records Exception (803(8))
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Public office record of activities, matters observed if duty to report, or factual findings
elements: Activities OR observations OR factual findings
exceptions: Police reports in criminal cases against defendant
common_traps: Using police reports against criminal defendant
evidence.teach: PUBLIC RECORDS = Government records reliable. BUT not police reports vs. criminal defendant.
evidence.question: Prosecutor offers police report in criminal case. Admissible as public record?
evidence.why: 803(8) specifically excludes law enforcement observations in criminal cases against defendant.

evidence.name: Former Testimony (804(b)(1))
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Prior testimony given as witness, declarant unavailable, party had opportunity to cross-examine
elements: Party had opportunity/similar motive to cross-examine
evidence.teach: FORMER TESTIMONY = Previous sworn testimony + similar motive to cross. Need unavailability.
evidence.question: Witness testified at preliminary hearing. Now unavailable. Admissible in trial?
evidence.why: Former testimony admissible if party (or predecessor) had similar motive to develop testimony.

evidence.name: Dying Declaration (804(b)(2))
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Statement under belief of imminent death concerning cause/circumstances of death
policy_rationales: Person about to meet Maker tells truth
evidence.teach: DYING DECLARATION = "I'm about to die, here's who killed me." Homicide or civil only.
evidence.question: Shooting victim believes he's dying, says "Joe shot me." Survives. Admissible in Joe's assault trial?
evidence.why: Dying declaration only admissible in homicide prosecutions (or civil). Assault = not homicide.

evidence.name: Statement Against Interest (804(b)(3))
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Statement against declarant's interest when made, declarant unavailable, reasonable person would not have made unless true
elements: Reasonable person wouldn't say unless true
exceptions: Statement exposing declarant to criminal liability needs corroboration
policy_rationales: People don't say things against their interest unless true
common_traps: Confusing with party admission (no unavailability needed for admission)
evidence.teach: AGAINST INTEREST = "This hurts me, but it's true." Need unavailability (unlike party admission).
evidence.question: Unavailable declarant said "I robbed the bank, not defendant." Admissible for defendant?
evidence.why: Statement exposing declarant to criminal liability admissible if corroborating circumstances show trustworthiness.

evidence.name: Forfeiture by Wrongdoing (804(b)(6))
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Party forfeits hearsay objection if wrongfully caused declarant's unavailability to prevent testimony
policy_rationales: Prevent party from benefiting from wrongdoing
evidence.teach: FORFEITURE = You killed witness to shut them up? You lose hearsay objection.
evidence.question: Defendant murders witness to prevent testimony. Witness's prior statements admissible?
evidence.why: Forfeiture by wrongdoing: party loses hearsay objection by wrongfully causing unavailability.

evidence.name: Residual Exception (807)
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Hearsay with equivalent guarantees of trustworthiness, material to issue, best available evidence, notice given
common_traps: Using as first resort (it's last resort)
evidence.teach: RESIDUAL = Catchall for reliable hearsay not fitting other exceptions. Last resort only.
evidence.question: Reliable hearsay not fitting 803/804. Can use residual exception without notice?
evidence.why: Residual exception requires pretrial notice to adverse party (or showing good cause for non-notice).

evidence.name: Party Admission (801(d)(2))
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Statement by party-opponent offered against that party (not hearsay by definition)
exceptions: Not hearsay, so no need for unavailability
policy_rationales: Party cannot complain about own statement
Adversarial system allows use against party
common_traps: Thinking it's an exception (it's not hearsay)
evidence.teach: PARTY ADMISSION = NOT hearsay. Your own words used against you. No unavailability needed.
evidence.question: Plaintiff offers defendant's prior statement against defendant. Hearsay exception needed?
evidence.why: Party admission is NOT hearsay by definition under 801(d)(2). No exception needed.

evidence.name: Co-Conspirator Statement (801(d)(2)(E))
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Statement by co-conspirator during and in furtherance of conspiracy
evidence.teach: CO-CONSPIRATOR = During + in furtherance of conspiracy. NOT casual chit-chat.
evidence.question: After arrest, co-conspirator says "We robbed the bank." Admissible against defendant?
evidence.why: After arrest = conspiracy ended. Must be during conspiracy and in furtherance.

evidence.name: Ancient Documents (803(16))
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Statement in document 20+ years old, authentic, in place expected if authentic
evidence.teach: ANCIENT DOCUMENTS = 20+ years old + looks real + found right place = reliable.
evidence.question: 25-year-old deed found in courthouse records. Admissible without foundation?
evidence.why: 20+ years old, authentic on face, proper place = ancient document exception.

evidence.name: Refreshing Recollection vs. Recorded Recollection
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Refreshing: witness uses anything to jog memory. Recorded recollection: 803(5) exception for past recording
elements: Refreshing: witness testifies from refreshed memory
Recorded: document admitted when witness still can't remember
exceptions: Refreshing: document not admitted, just used
Recorded: requires foundation (made when fresh, accurate, now can't remember)
common_traps: Thinking refreshing document comes in as evidence
evidence.teach: REFRESHING = Jog memory, doc stays out. RECORDED RECOLLECTION = Can't remember even after, doc comes in (803(5)).
evidence.question: Witness looks at notes, now remembers. Notes admissible as evidence?
evidence.why: Refreshing recollection: witness testifies from memory, document not admitted.

evidence.name: Character Evidence - Criminal Defendant
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Defendant may offer evidence of pertinent good character trait; prosecution may rebut
common_traps: Thinking prosecution can start with character
evidence.teach: DEFENDANT CHARACTER = Defendant opens door with good character. Prosecution can rebut. Reputation/opinion only.
evidence.question: Can prosecution start case by proving defendant's bad character for violence?
evidence.why: Prosecution cannot initiate character evidence. Defendant must open door first (404(a)(2)(A)).

evidence.name: Character Evidence - Victim in Criminal Case
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Defendant may offer victim's pertinent character; prosecution may rebut and offer defendant's same trait
elements: Prosecution rebounds with defendant's same trait
policy_rationales: Self-defense claims need victim aggression evidence
common_traps: Missing "same trait" requirement for prosecution rebuttal
evidence.teach: VICTIM CHARACTER = Defense offers victim aggression → Prosecution offers defendant aggression (same trait).
evidence.question: Self-defense case. Defense offers victim's violent character. Prosecution can offer defendant's what?
evidence.why: Prosecution may rebut with defendant's character for SAME TRAIT (violence here).

evidence.name: Prior Bad Acts (404(b))
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Evidence of other crimes/wrongs inadmissible to prove propensity but admissible for MIMIC purposes
elements: MIMIC: Motive, Intent, Mistake (absence), Identity, Common plan
evidence.teach: PRIOR BAD ACTS = NO for propensity. YES for MIMIC (Motive Intent Mistake Identity Common plan).
evidence.question: Prosecution offers defendant's prior robbery to show he's a robber in current robbery case. Admissible?
evidence.why: To show "he's a robber" = propensity use. Inadmissible under 404(b).

evidence.name: Methods of Proving Character (405)
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Character proved by reputation/opinion; specific acts allowed on cross or if character is essential element
elements: Specific acts if essential element of claim
common_traps: Allowing specific acts on direct (except essential element)
Missing good faith basis for cross
evidence.teach: CHARACTER METHODS = Reputation/opinion on direct. Specific acts ONLY on cross (or if essential element).
evidence.question: Direct examination of character witness. Can ask about specific good acts?
evidence.why: Direct examination: reputation or opinion only. Specific acts allowed only on cross.

evidence.name: Habit Evidence (406)
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Evidence of habit or routine practice admissible to prove conformity
elements: Habit = specific response to repeated situation
evidence.teach: HABIT = Specific + regular + automatic. "Always do X in situation Y." Admissible to prove conduct.
evidence.question: "Plaintiff always stops at that stop sign" - admissible to show stopped on day in question?
evidence.why: Specific regular behavior (always stops at same sign) = habit. Admissible under 406.

evidence.name: Character for Truthfulness (608)
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Witness credibility may be attacked/supported by testimony about character for truthfulness
elements: Only after credibility attacked for support
Specific acts on cross with good faith basis
evidence.teach: TRUTHFULNESS = Attack credibility anytime. Support ONLY after attack. Reputation/opinion; specific acts on cross only.
evidence.question: Can plaintiff support own witness's truthfulness before any attack?
evidence.why: Cannot bolster witness credibility before credibility attacked (608(a)).

evidence.name: Impeachment by Conviction (609)
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Prior conviction admissible for impeachment if crime of dishonesty OR felony passing 403 balance
elements: 10-year limit unless probative value substantially outweighs prejudice
evidence.teach: CONVICTION IMPEACHMENT = Dishonesty crimes always. Felonies if pass 403 (reverse for crim defendant). 10-year limit.
evidence.question: Criminal defendant testifies. 12-year-old felony conviction. Admissible to impeach?
evidence.why: Convictions 10+ years old admissible ONLY if probative value substantially outweighs prejudice.

evidence.name: Character Evidence in Sexual Assault Cases (413-415)
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: In sexual assault/child molestation cases, defendant's prior similar acts admissible for any purpose including propensity
elements: Sexual assault or child molestation case
exceptions: Special rules only for sexual offenses
policy_rationales: Pattern of sexual offenses highly probative
evidence.teach: SEXUAL ASSAULT = Special rule. Prior similar acts admissible for propensity. Exception to general 404(b) rule.
evidence.question: Rape prosecution. Evidence of defendant's prior rape 5 years ago. Admissible for propensity?
evidence.why: Rule 413: prior sexual assault admissible for any purpose including propensity in sexual assault cases.

evidence.name: Attorney-Client Privilege
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Confidential communications between attorney and client for legal advice privileged
common_traps: Forgetting waiver by disclosure to third party
evidence.teach: ATTORNEY-CLIENT = Confidential communications for legal advice. NOT facts, NOT future crimes.
evidence.question: Client tells lawyer "I plan to commit tax fraud." Privileged?
evidence.why: Crime-fraud exception: communications in furtherance of future crime/fraud not privileged.

evidence.name: Work Product Doctrine
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Attorney's trial preparation materials protected from discovery absent substantial need
elements: Core work product (mental impressions) strongly protected
exceptions: Substantial need + undue hardship to obtain equivalent
Core work product almost never discoverable
evidence.teach: WORK PRODUCT = Attorney trial prep protected. Core mental impressions = super protected.
evidence.question: Attorney's notes analyzing case strategy. Discoverable if opponent shows substantial need?
evidence.why: Core work product (mental impressions, strategies) protected even with substantial need.

evidence.name: Spousal Immunity (Testimonial Privilege)
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Married person may refuse to testify against spouse in criminal case
elements: Valid marriage at time of trial
common_traps: Who holds privilege varies by jurisdiction
evidence.teach: SPOUSAL IMMUNITY = Married now? Can refuse to testify against spouse (criminal only). Witness holds privilege.
evidence.question: Husband charged with tax fraud. Wife witness to fraud. Must wife testify?
evidence.why: Spousal immunity (testimonial privilege): witness spouse may refuse to testify in criminal case.

evidence.name: Marital Communications Privilege
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Confidential communications between spouses during valid marriage privileged
exceptions: Not confidential if third party present
evidence.teach: MARITAL COMMUNICATIONS = Said during marriage in confidence? Privileged forever. Both spouses hold it.
evidence.question: Husband told wife "I committed fraud" during marriage. Now divorced. Wife can testify?
evidence.why: Marital communications privilege survives divorce. Communication during marriage protected.

evidence.name: Psychotherapist-Patient Privilege
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Confidential communications to licensed psychotherapist for diagnosis/treatment privileged
evidence.teach: PSYCHOTHERAPIST = Mental health treatment confidential. Patient holds privilege.
evidence.question: Patient sues for emotional distress, putting mental state at issue. Therapy communications privileged?
evidence.why: Patient-litigant exception: by putting mental state at issue, patient waives psychotherapist privilege.

evidence.name: Physician-Patient Privilege
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: In some states, communications to physician for treatment privileged (not in federal law)
evidence.teach: PHYSICIAN-PATIENT = State privilege only (NO federal privilege). Patient-litigant exception common.
evidence.question: Federal court diversity case. State has physician-patient privilege. Applies in federal court?
evidence.why: FRE 501: state law privileges apply in diversity cases. Federal common law in federal question cases.

evidence.name: Privilege Waiver
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Privilege waived by voluntary disclosure or by putting privileged matter at issue
exceptions: Inadvertent disclosure (may not waive if steps taken)
Partial disclosure may waive all on topic
policy_rationales: Cannot use privilege as shield and sword
evidence.teach: PRIVILEGE WAIVER = Disclose to third party OR put at issue = lose privilege. Can't have it both ways.
evidence.question: Client tells friend what lawyer said. Attorney-client privilege waived?
evidence.why: Voluntary disclosure to third party waives attorney-client privilege. No longer confidential.

evidence.name: Daubert Standard for Expert Testimony
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Expert testimony admissible if scientific knowledge will help trier of fact and reliable methodology
evidence.teach: DAUBERT = Federal standard. Reliable methodology + helpful = admissible. Judge is gatekeeper.
evidence.question: Expert uses novel scientific method not peer-reviewed. Admissible under Daubert?
evidence.why: Peer review is one Daubert factor, not requirement. Judge has discretion as gatekeeper.

evidence.name: Frye Standard (General Acceptance)
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Scientific evidence admissible if methodology generally accepted in relevant scientific community
evidence.teach: FRYE = Old standard. Generally accepted in scientific community? Some states still use.
evidence.question: State court using Frye. Novel but reliable scientific method. Admissible?
evidence.why: Under Frye, must be generally accepted in scientific community. Novel = not accepted yet.

evidence.name: Expert Testimony Requirements (FRE 702)
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Expert may testify if qualified and testimony based on sufficient facts/data and reliable principles reliably applied
evidence.teach: FRE 702 = Qualified + reliable principles reliably applied + helpful = admissible expert testimony.
evidence.question: Doctor uses reliable medical principles but applies them incorrectly. Admissible under 702?
evidence.why: Must reliably APPLY principles, not just use reliable principles. Application matters.

evidence.name: Bases of Expert Opinion (FRE 703)
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Expert may base opinion on facts/data reasonably relied upon by experts in field, even if inadmissible
elements: Facts reasonably relied upon in field
Probative value vs. prejudice (if disclosed to jury)
common_traps: Thinking expert can only use admissible evidence
evidence.teach: FRE 703 = Expert can use inadmissible evidence as basis if reasonably relied upon in field.
evidence.question: Expert bases opinion on hearsay report. Can expert testify to opinion?
evidence.why: Expert can base opinion on inadmissible evidence if reasonably relied upon by experts in field.

evidence.name: Opinion on Ultimate Issue (FRE 704)
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Expert may opine on ultimate issue except in criminal cases regarding defendant's mental state
exceptions: Cannot testify defendant had/lacked mental state in criminal case
policy_rationales: But protect criminal defendants from dispositive expert testimony
evidence.teach: FRE 704 = Expert CAN opine on ultimate issue (except criminal defendant mental state).
evidence.question: Civil case. Can expert testify "Defendant was negligent"?
evidence.why: Ultimate issue testimony permitted under 704. Expert may opine on negligence in civil case.

evidence.name: Lay vs. Expert Opinion (FRE 701 vs. 702)
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Lay opinion admissible if rationally based on perception and helpful; expert opinion for specialized knowledge
elements: Lay: cannot be based on scientific/technical knowledge
common_traps: Allowing lay witnesses to give expert opinions
evidence.teach: LAY OPINION (701) = What you saw/experienced. EXPERT (702) = Specialized knowledge needed.
evidence.question: Lay witness: "Car was going 70 mph." Admissible as lay opinion?
evidence.why: Speed estimation from observation = lay opinion (701). Rationally based on perception.

evidence.name: Prior Inconsistent Statement (613)
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Witness may be impeached by showing prior inconsistent statement if given opportunity to explain
elements: Extrinsic evidence allowed if opportunity given
exceptions: May use without opportunity if witness still available
common_traps: Using extrinsic evidence on collateral matters
evidence.teach: PRIOR INCONSISTENT = Said X before, Y now? Shows unreliable. Give chance to explain.
evidence.question: Impeach with prior statement. Must confront witness with statement first?
evidence.why: Need opportunity to explain but can give at any time. Modern rule allows extrinsic evidence if opportunity given.

evidence.name: Impeachment by Bias
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Witness may be impeached by showing bias, prejudice, or motive to lie
common_traps: Thinking collateral matter rule applies to bias
evidence.teach: BIAS = Always relevant to impeach. NOT collateral. Can use extrinsic evidence.
evidence.question: Witness is plaintiff's brother. Can cross-examine about relationship to show bias?
evidence.why: Bias always relevant to credibility. Family relationship shows potential bias/motive.

evidence.name: Impeachment by Sensory/Mental Deficiency
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Witness may be impeached by showing deficiency in capacity to observe, remember, or relate
policy_rationales: Test ability to perceive and relate
evidence.teach: SENSORY/MENTAL = Could witness see/hear/remember? Affects ability to testify accurately.
evidence.question: Witness was drunk at time of observation. Can cross-examine about intoxication?
evidence.why: Intoxication at time of observation affects ability to perceive. Relevant to impeach.

evidence.name: Impeachment by Contradiction
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Witness may be impeached by showing testimony contradicted by other evidence
elements: May use extrinsic evidence if not collateral
common_traps: Using extrinsic evidence on collateral matters
evidence.teach: CONTRADICTION = Witness wrong about something? If not collateral, can prove up. If collateral, stuck with answer.
evidence.question: Cross: "Didn't you wear blue shirt?" Witness: "No, red." Can call second witness to prove blue shirt?
evidence.why: Shirt color = collateral matter (not relevant to case). Cannot use extrinsic evidence. Stuck with answer.

evidence.name: Rehabilitation of Witness
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: After credibility attacked, witness may be rehabilitated by prior consistent statement or character for truthfulness
elements: Prior consistent statement if charge of recent fabrication/improper motive
Character for truthfulness if character attacked
exceptions: Prior consistent must predate motive to fabricate
common_traps: Using prior consistent without fabrication charge
evidence.teach: REHABILITATION = Credibility attacked? Can rehabilitate with prior consistent (if motive charged) or character.
evidence.question: Witness impeached by prior inconsistent statement. Can rehabilitate with character evidence?
evidence.why: Character for truthfulness only if character attacked. Prior inconsistent may not be character attack.

evidence.name: Religious Beliefs Inadmissible for Credibility (610)
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Cannot impeach or support credibility by evidence of religious beliefs or opinions
exceptions: May show bias/interest if religion relevant to bias
evidence.teach: RELIGIOUS BELIEFS = Cannot impeach or support credibility. Off limits under 610.
evidence.question: Cross-examination: "You're an atheist, correct?" to attack credibility. Permissible?
evidence.why: FRE 610 prohibits using religious beliefs (or lack thereof) to attack credibility.

evidence.name: Relevance Definition (FRE 401)
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Evidence relevant if it has any tendency to make fact more or less probable
elements: Tendency to make fact more/less probable
evidence.teach: RELEVANCE = ANY tendency to make fact more/less probable. Very low bar.
evidence.question: Evidence makes fact 1% more probable. Relevant under 401?
evidence.why: ANY tendency sufficient for relevance. Even 1% probability increase = relevant under 401.

evidence.name: Exclusion for Unfair Prejudice (FRE 403)
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Court may exclude relevant evidence if probative value substantially outweighed by unfair prejudice
elements: Confusion, waste of time also considered
evidence.teach: FRE 403 = Probative value SUBSTANTIALLY outweighed by unfair prejudice? High bar to exclude.
evidence.question: Gruesome photo relevant to injury. Prejudicial to defendant. Admissible?
evidence.why: High bar for 403 exclusion. Probative value must be SUBSTANTIALLY outweighed. Damaging ≠ unfairly prejudicial.

evidence.name: Authentication (FRE 901)
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Evidence must be authenticated by showing it is what proponent claims
elements: Sufficient evidence for jury to find authentic
evidence.teach: AUTHENTICATION = Show it's what you claim. Low bar - enough for jury to find authentic.
evidence.question: Letter claimed written by defendant. How authenticate?
evidence.why: Authentication: any evidence sufficient to support finding it's what claimed. Multiple methods OK.

evidence.name: Best Evidence Rule (FRE 1002)
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Original document required to prove contents of writing, recording, or photograph
exceptions: Excuses: lost, destroyed, in opponent possession
Not needed if not proving contents
evidence.teach: BEST EVIDENCE = Proving contents of document? Need original or duplicate (unless excused).
evidence.question: Witness testifies to what he saw at event. Event was photographed. Need photo?
evidence.why: Best evidence rule only applies when proving CONTENTS. Witness testifying to observation, not photo contents.

evidence.name: Subsequent Remedial Measures (FRE 407)
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Evidence of repairs/changes after event inadmissible to prove negligence/defect but admissible for other purposes
elements: Admissible for: ownership, control, feasibility, impeachment
evidence.teach: SUBSEQUENT REMEDIAL = Fixed it after? Can't prove negligence/defect. BUT can prove control, feasibility, impeach.
evidence.question: After accident, defendant fixed stairs. Admissible to prove owned stairs?
evidence.why: Subsequent remedial inadmissible for negligence/defect but admissible to prove ownership/control.

evidence.name: Settlement Negotiations (FRE 408)
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Settlement offers and negotiations inadmissible to prove/disprove validity or amount of claim
elements: Admissible for bias, undue delay, obstruction
exceptions: Can use for other purposes (bias, etc.)
Statements to government agencies not protected
common_traps: Thinking statements protected in criminal cases
evidence.teach: SETTLEMENT = Can't use offers to prove liability/amount. Encourage compromise. Criminal ≠ protected.
evidence.question: Settlement offer in civil case. Admissible in later criminal case?
evidence.why: 408 protection only in case being compromised. Later criminal case = no protection.

evidence.name: Pleas and Plea Discussions (FRE 410)
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Withdrawn guilty pleas, nolo contendere pleas, and plea discussions inadmissible
exceptions: Defendant may use own plea statements
common_traps: Thinking accepted guilty plea protected (it's not)
evidence.teach: PLEA DISCUSSIONS = Withdrawn pleas + nolo + plea talks = inadmissible. Encourage negotiation.
evidence.question: Defendant withdrew guilty plea. Can prosecution use plea in trial?
evidence.why: FRE 410: withdrawn guilty pleas inadmissible. Encourage plea negotiations.

evidence.name: Liability Insurance (FRE 411)
evidence.subject: evidence
evidence.rule_statement: Evidence of liability insurance inadmissible to prove negligence or ability to pay but admissible for other purposes
elements: Inadmissible for negligence or ability to pay
evidence.teach: LIABILITY INSURANCE = Can't prove negligence. BUT can prove bias, ownership, control.
evidence.question: Witness works for defendant's insurer. Can cross-examine about employment to show bias?
evidence.why: Liability insurance inadmissible for negligence but admissible to show bias of witness.

real_property.name: ESTATES & FUTURE INTERESTS
real_property.subject: real_property
real_property.rule_statement: Present estates include fee simple, life estates, and leaseholds; future interests vest in grantor or third parties subject to RAP, waste, and defeasibility doctrines.

real_property.name: CONVEYANCING & RECORDING
real_property.subject: real_property
real_property.rule_statement: Valid conveyance needs competent grantor, executed deed, delivery, and acceptance; recording acts protect bona fide purchasers without notice who record first depending on statute type.

real_property.name: ESTATES & FUTURE INTERESTS
real_property.subject: real_property
real_property.rule_statement: Present possessory estates include fee simple absolute, defeasible fees, and life estates; future interests include reversions, remainders, and executory interests that must satisfy RAP.
common_traps: AUTO vs. MANUAL: Determinable = AUTOmatic (like autopilot); Condition Subsequent = MANUAL reentry (like manual transmission)
REMAINDER RULE: Remainders are like train passengers - they wait for their turn, never jump ahead (never executory)
RAP TRAP: 21 years + lives in being = drinking age (21) + pregnancy (gestation)

real_property.name: CONVEYANCING & RECORDING
real_property.subject: real_property
real_property.rule_statement: Recording statutes protect bona fide purchasers; race-notice is majority rule, requiring timely recordation without notice of prior interests.
common_traps: BFP = Good Faith Penny: Bona fide purchaser needs good faith + value (even $1) + no notice
Chain Gang: Must examine entire chain of title, not just immediate grantor (like prison chain gang - all connected)
Triple Notice Threat: Actual (you know) + Constructive (recorded) + Inquiry (should have known)

real_property.name: EASEMENTS, SERVITUDES & LICENSES
real_property.subject: real_property
real_property.rule_statement: Easements create rights to use another's land; appurtenant easements run with land, in gross are personal; licenses are revocable permissions.

real_property.name: CONCURRENT OWNERSHIP
real_property.subject: real_property
real_property.rule_statement: Joint tenancy requires four unities; tenancy in common has no survivorship; tenancy by entirety protects marital property from separate creditors.

real_property.name: LANDLORD-TENANT LAW
real_property.subject: real_property
real_property.rule_statement: Landlord must maintain habitable premises; tenant must pay rent; holdover becomes periodic tenancy; self-help eviction is illegal in most states.

real_property.name: MORTGAGES, FORECLOSURE & PRIORITY
real_property.subject: real_property
real_property.rule_statement: Mortgage creates security interest; foreclosure terminates mortgagor's equity; purchase money mortgages have super-priority over later liens on same collateral.

real_property.name: ZONING & TAKINGS
real_property.subject: real_property
real_property.rule_statement: Zoning regulates land use; takings require just compensation; variance is exception to zoning rules for hardship; exactions must be roughly proportional.

real_property.name: ADVERSE POSSESSION
real_property.subject: real_property
real_property.rule_statement: Hostile, actual, exclusive, continuous possession for statutory period perfects title; color of title reduces period to 7 years.

real_property.name: FIXTURES
real_property.subject: real_property
real_property.rule_statement: Personal property becomes real property when permanently attached with intent to improve the realty; trade fixtures remain personal property.

real_property.name: Easement by Necessity
real_property.subject: real_property
real_property.rule_statement: Implied easement when landlocked

real_property.name: Easement by Prescription
real_property.subject: real_property
real_property.rule_statement: Open, notorious, continuous adverse use

real_property.name: Covenant - Touch and Concern
real_property.subject: real_property
real_property.rule_statement: Burden/benefit must relate to land use
